instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message:
Howdy folks,

Building on another post: [URL="https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/17218-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b-green-light-on-charger-no-power-on-missing-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>"]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards...ssing-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>[/URL]

Same issue. Green light all G3H rails OK but at <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and down all I get is pulsing.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> does not pulse at <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> but does pulse everywhere else.

Also pulsing are:
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>

Replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, issue persists.
First time I see this, not sure where to go from here.

Power draw on PSU jumps from 0.008 to 0.036, occasional spike to 0.166 amps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message: History? What does <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> have to do with <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>? PPBUS voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message:
History unknown but doesn’t look like anyone has been in here before. <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> is also on that line according to the boardview so that’s where I also measured, is my bv messed up?

PPBUS at 18.5v, drawing from memory so if that’s not accurate I can re-messure later. Number looked right at time of measuring else I’d have made note of it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message: Stop using the BV as a schematic. BV is only for reference when looking up stuff, verify on the schematic. PPBUS at 18V would be bad...check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message:
Noted.
PPBUS fluctuates rapidly between 12.04 and 12.6V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message: Check all rails for shorts. Check resistance between pins 17/18, 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Was the GPU messed with?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message:
Resistance 17/18 = 2.6ohm, 27/28 = 20.3ohm. GPU has not been messed with from what I can tell.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 7.4 mega Ohm and dropping
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5</SIGNAL> rails = 5.7 mega Ohm and dropping (keeping same value as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.L
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 12 kilo Ohm
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>  = 093.5 kilo Ohm
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> = 073.8 kilo Ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power pulsing rails
threads.message: There are a lot more power rails than that!
